p: Carrageenans are widely used as an inflammatory inducing agent in experimental animals [ 134], and have also been proposed for the immobilization and encapsulation of biocatalysts [ 135], for entrapping lactic bacteria and enzymes [ 136], for microencapsulation of probiotics in mixtures of k-carrageenan with carboxymethylcellulose [ 137]. Recent pharmaceutical applications are found in drug delivery and for tissue regeneration [ 138]. Carrageenans are highly biocompatible and are used as ingredients for films, beads, microparticles, nanoparticles, hydrogels, inhalable and injectable systems [ 107, 108, 139] used alone or in combination with other polymers, and its mucoadhesive properties have been exploited in the preparation of aerogel microparticles for mucosal drug delivery [ 140].
